discussion.content:
Answer A.

You can take advantage of the safety and reliability of geographic redundancy by spanning your Auto Scaling group across multiple Availability Zones within a region and then attaching a load bal-ancer to distribute incoming traffic across those Availability Zones. Incoming traffic is distributed equally across all Availability Zones enabled for your load balancer.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AutoScaling/latest/DeveloperGuide/GettingStartedTutorial.html

questions.answer_description:

Incoming traffic is distributed equally across all Availability
Zones enabled for your load balancer.
Reference:

questions.question_text: In which screen does a user select the Availability Zones while configuring Auto Scaling?

questions.answer_description:
CloudWatch provides the basic monitoring metrics (at five-minute frequency), 10 metrics (applica-ble to detailed monitoring for the Amazon EC2 instances or custom metrics), 10 alarms, and 1 mil-lion API requests each month at no additional charge.
Reference:
http://aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/pricing/
questions.question_text: Which of the CloudWatch services mentioned below is NOT a part of the AWS free tier?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
10 Detailed Monitoring Metrics (at 1-minute frequency)
https://aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/pricing/?nc1=h_ls

Selected Answer: A
In the context of sending metrics to CloudWatch using Amazon Kinesis, the metric "PutRecord.Latency" represents the time taken per PutRecord operation. It measures the duration of each individual PutRecord operation, capturing the latency from when the record is received until it is successfully stored in the Kinesis stream. This metric provides insights into the performance and efficiency of individual PutRecord operations.

The time taken per PutRecord operation, measured over the specified time period.

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/streams/latest/dev/monitoring-with-cloudwatch.html

Default answer is right : Answer A

Full of D option: It is the number of successful PutRecord operations per Amazon Kinesis stream, measured over the specified time period.
Ans: A

choices.A: It is the time taken per PutRecord operation, measured over the specified time period.
choices.C: It is the time taken per PutRecords operation to calculate the statistics of the PutRecords opera-tions.
choices.D: It is the number of successful PutRecord operations per Amazon Kinesis stream, measured over the specified time period.
choices.B: It is the number of successful records in a PutRecords operation per Amazon Kinesis stream, measured over the specified time period.

questions.question_text: In the context of sending metrics to CloudWatch using Amazon Kinesis, which of the following statements best describes the metric "PutRecord.Latency"?
questions.answer_description:
The metric PutRecord.Latency measures the time taken per PutRecord operation, measured over the specified time period.

Dimensions: StreamName -
Statistics: Minimum, Maximum, Average

Units: Milliseconds -
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/kinesis/latest/dev/monitoring_with_cloudwatch.html

choices.C: No, a user cannot plot several metrics on a single graph since the units are different.
choices.B: Yes, a user can graph several metrics over time on a single graph.
choices.A: No, a user cannot graph two separate metrics on the same graph.
choices.D: Yes, a user can graph multiple metrics on the same graph provided they are of the same instance in the same AZ.

questions.question_text: Can a user depict CloudWatch metrics such as CPU utilization in % and Network I/O in bytes on a single graph?
questions.answer_description:
You can graph several metrics over time on the same graph. The user can select metrics across re-sources and graph them on a single graph. It is not required that they should be of the same instance. They can be of different instances with the same AMI or based on some other dimension. You can filter records and plot them all on the same graph.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudWatch/latest/DeveloperGuide/graph_a_metric_all_resources.html

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
In CloudWatch, a user can graph several metrics over time on a single graph. This allows for visualizing and comparing multiple metrics simultaneously. For example, it is possible to depict CPU utilization in percentage and Network I/O in bytes on the same graph. CloudWatch provides the flexibility to choose multiple metrics from the same or different AWS resources and plot them together, providing a comprehensive view of the system's performance.

comments.content:
Here is D.Yes, a user can graph multiple metrics on the same graph provided they are of the same instance in the same AZ. 
What do you think the correct answer should be? B or D

questions.question_text: Which of the following comes before Auto Scaling group creation?
questions.answer_description:
The Auto Scaling launch config is the first step that should be run before a user can create an Auto Scaling group. The launch config has all the information, such as the instance type, AMI ID, and other instance launch parameters. The Auto Scaling group uses this launch config to create a new group.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AutoScaling/latest/DeveloperGuide/LaunchConfiguration.html

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Before creating an Auto Scaling group, the user typically creates the Auto Scaling launch configuration. The launch configuration defines the parameters for the instances that will be launched by the Auto Scaling group, such as the Amazon Machine Image (AMI), instance type, security groups, and key pair. The launch configuration acts as a template for the instances launched by the Auto Scaling group.

choices.A: Creating the Auto Scaling launch config
